metadata.title: Enhancing the Thermal and Upper Voltage Performance of Ni-Rich Cathode Material by a Homogeneous and Facile Coating Method: Spray-Drying Coating with Nano-Al2O3

sections.text: KEYWORDS: Ni-rich cathode material, LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2, spray-drying coating, nano-Al2O3, high temperature, upper voltage

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Consumer electronics, such as mobile phones, laptops, digital cameras, and electric vehicles (EVs), are advancing rapidly with each passing day, creating a demand for better power sources. Therefore, high-energy-density lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with longer cycle life and better safety are in demand, as they are expected to be widely used in device applications.1,2 Thus, intensive research on LIBs has been implemented to meet the demand with a higher degree of lithium utilization and specific energy density.3−5 As the cathode materials used in the LIBs are the core of the performance, most research efforts have been focused on them, either to develop alternative cathode materials or to modify the available ones.6,7 Layered lithium Nirich compounds LiNi1−xMxO2 (0.1 < x < 0.5, M = Mn, Co, Al, etc.) are considered as promising candidates to meet such requirements for next-generation LIBs because of their relatively high capacity (>180 mA h g−1) as well as greater accessibility to the conventional LiCoO2.
8−10 In particular, some of these Ni-rich LiNi1−xMxO2 cathode materials have been applied in electric vehicles. For example, LIBs with LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 (NCA) have already been utilized successfully in Tesla electric vehicles, representing great progress. The LIB approach with LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 cathode material has been regarded as the most accessible high-energydensity storage device to date.9
However, Ni-rich cathode materials suffer from severe capacity fading, especially at high temperature and in the highly delithiated state at elevated voltages (>4.3 V) because of the increasing impedance and structural instability.11,12 The thermal instability would even lead to serious safety problems during thermal runaway. Among the major reasons for this are side reactions with CO2 in the air and moisture on the surface. Excess LiOH is necessary in the preparation process, and residual lithium still remaining on the surface of the cathode materials can react directly with air. The ability of rapid moisture uptake of Ni-rich cathode materials also results in the formation of impurities, such as LiF, Li2CO3, and LiOH. 13,14 Spontaneous side reactions also take place on the surface of the Ni-rich cathode materials when in direct contact with electrolytes.15 These impurities exist on the cathode materials’ surface would hinder the Li+ ion diffusion during the charge− discharge process because of their insulation, leading to deterioration of the electrochemical performance.16,17 Apart from that, upon exposure to air, reduction of Ni3+ to Ni2+
occurring on the cathode materials’ surface would also lead to the formation of LiOH, LiHCO3, Li2CO3, and NiO-like

materials on the surface. Any residue on the surface worsens the cathode materials’ machining performance and electrochemical performance.18
To solve the above problems, intensive work has been performed during the recent years. Although there are no methods that are efficacious forever, coating the surfaces with nanoscale layers is regarded as a practicable one.19 Since the initial report of a B2O3 oxide coating to modify cathode materials by Amatucci,20 various coating materials and methods have been explored to improve the performance, such as Al2O3, 21−23 SiO2, 24 TiO2, 25 MgO,26 ZrO2, 27 V2O5, 18,28 AlF3, 29,30 Ni3PO4, 31 and LiCoO2. 32 The coating layer mainly acts as an isolation layer to prevent side reactions. The main coating techniques include sol−gel,33 solvothermal method,34 chemical deposition,35 magnetron sputtering,36 and atomic layer deposition.22,23 Although these coating progresses have improved the performance, it is still difficult to ensure the homogeneity of the coating layer and avoid self-nucleation of the coating material. Spray drying is a rapid-drying method that uses hot gas to produce dry powders rapidly from a liquid or slurry.37 The drying speed using a spray drier is very high, as the specific area increases sharply after the liquid droplets atomize, and 95−98% of the water vaporizes instantly in the high-temperature air flow within only several seconds. Especially, products dried by spray drying are consistent, having good uniformity, dispersion, mobility, and solubility. Thus, it is a preferred drying method applied to produce many thermally sensitive materials such as foods and pharmaceuticals. Meanwhile, this method is commonly used in industry, and it has also been adapted to prepare nanoporous spherical lithium-ion cathode materials, such as LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2, 38 LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2, 39 LiNi0.8Co0.2O2, 40 Co3O4,
41 and so on. However, most researchers have just focused on the synthesis materials by spray drying. In this work, spray-drying coating (SDC) of the Ni-rich cathode materials with nano-Al2O3 is proposed, and LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 is taken as an example. This new approach results in an Al2O3 layer distributed uniformly on the precursor and a LiAlO2 layer on the as-prepared cathode material, which improves the structural and thermal stability under conditions such as elevated temperature (>50 °C) and upper cutoff voltage (>4.3 V).

sections.heading: 2. EXPERIMENTAL SECTION
sections.text:
2 .1 . Mate r i a l s Syn thes i s . The u s ed p r e c u r s o r Ni0.8Co0.15Al0.05(OH)2 was commercially supplied (Jintian Energy Co. Ltd., China). Ni0.8Co0.15Al0.05(OH)2 and nano-Al2O3 sol−gel (Al2O3 > 20%; Xilong Chemical Co., Ltd., China) were used as starting materials with mass ratios of 99:1, 98:2, and 95:5. The process is shown in Scheme 1, first nano-Al2O3 sol−gel is dissolved in distilled water and agitated for dispersion for 4 h using a high-energy tip sonicator (400 W, KQ-400 KDE, Kun Shan Ultrasonic Instruments Co., Ltd., China). Then Ni0.8Co0.15Al0.05(OH)2 precursor is added to the solution, followed by ultrasonical mixing for 1 h. The resulting solution is dried rapidly via a commercial spray drying process, from which a coated dry precursor is obtained. For this, the atomizer used was a two-fluid nozzle, and the atomization pressure in the process was set to 0.3 bar. The mixed solution is turned into a spray of small droplets, and once the droplets are generated, they are flown into an electronic furnace via an air flow, in which the droplets are dried. The coated dry precursor particles are gathered to the cyclone walls, while in contrast, the lighter, moist air is separated from the particles and directed away through the exhaust pipes. The inlet and outlet temperatures of the spray dryer in the process were set at 180 and 110 °C, respectively. Conditions such as the feeding speed and solution
concentration were strictly controlled during the process. The obtained Ni0.8Co0.15Al0.05(OH)2/Al2O3 composite spheres is ground thoroughly in an agate mortar with LiOH·H2O in a molar ratio of 1:1.05. After mixing well for 40 min, the prepared mixtures are first preheated at 550 °C for 4 h in air and then annealed at 750 °C for 12 h in a continuous flow of O2, from which LiAlO2-coated LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 powders are obtained. Three coated samples with 1%, 2%, and 5% Al2O3 coating are represented as SDCNCA1, SDCNCA2, and SDCNCA5, respectively.
2.2. Material Characterizations. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) (D/max-r A-type diffractometer, Cu Kα1 radiation, 40 kV, 300 mA, Rigaku, Japan) was employed to identify the crystalline phases of the synthesized precursor and as-prepared materials. XRD data were gathered over the 2θ range from 10° to 80°. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDX) (JSM-6360LV scanning electron microscope, JEOL, Japan) were applied to observe the morphology of the particles and the distributions of elements on the surface. To find the interior Al distribution, cross sections for SEM analysis of the samples were obtained by embedding the as-coated LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 particles in an epoxy and then grinding the compound on metallographic sand papers. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) (Tecnai G12 microscope) was applied to observe the microstructures of the SDCNCA samples. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) were conducted on a STA-449C instrument (Netzsch, Germany) at a heating speed of 5 °C min−1 under an Ar atmosphere.
2.3. Electrochemical Evaluation. The cathode was prepared by blending the active material, acetylene black, and poly(vinyl difluoride) (PVDF) binder in a mass ratio of 8:1:1, dispersing the blend in Nmethylpyrrolidinone (NMP) in an agate mortar, and then coating the dispersion onto an Al foil. The as-prepared cathode foil was dried under vacuum at 120 °C for 12 h to eliminate the NMP solvent and then assembled a CR2025 coin cell with a lithium metal anode and a porous polypropylene film using 1 mol L−1 LiPF6 in 1:1:1 (v/v/v) ethylene carbonate/ethyl methyl carbonate/dimethyl carbonate solvent as the electrolyte in an argon-filled glovebox. All of the electrochemical properties were cycled galvanostatically between 2.8 and 4.3 V (vs Li+/Li), and the current density of 1C was set as 180 mA g−1. The initial charge−discharge curves were evaluated at a rate of 0.1 C at room temperature, while the cycle performance was evaluated at room temperature at a rate of 1 C for 150 cycles. The upper cutoff voltage was set at 4.4 or 4.5 V. The cells were also tested at 55 °C. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was conducted after 100 cycles with a frequency range from 0.01 to 100 kHz.

sections.heading: 3. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text:
3.1. Material Characterizations. Figure S1 shows the XRD profiles of the pristine Ni0.8Co0.15Al0.05(OH)2 precursor and the Al2O3-coated precursors. As can be seen, the diffraction peak positions for all of the coated samples are the same as for
Scheme 1. Typical Spray-Drying Coating (SDC) Process
DOI: 10.1021/acsami.6b05629 ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2016, 8, 17713−17720
17714
the pristine one, which matches well with that of Ni(OH)2. The typical phase structure of the LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 particles and the as-coated samples were analyzed by XRD, as displayed in Figure S2. All of the samples display clear diffraction peaks, and the SDCNCA samples exhibit the same diffraction peaks as the pristine NCA with no significant difference in the phase structure. These samples are all single-phase and isostructural with LiNiO2, whose diffraction patterns are related to the hexagonal α-NaFeO2 structure with space group R3 ̅m. This indicates that spray-drying coating with nano-Al2O3 does not cause any noticeable change in the crystal structure. Figure 1 displays the surface morphology difference of the SDCNCA precursors and the pristine one. Although after being
coated the SDCNCA precursors retain a spherical morphology in their secondary particles as does the pristine precursor, there are significant differences on the surface. As shown in Figure 1a, it is clear that the primary particles of the pristine precursor are needle-like and the secondary forms are densely agglomerated. However, after nano-Al2O3 spray coating on the precursor, the needle-like primary particles are covered by a uniform and tight layer. This can be presumed to be the nano-Al2O3 layer, and it is uniformly distributed on the surface of the precursor. To further confirm the change of the Al distribution on the surface, EDX was conduced, and the results are shown in Figures S3 and S4. It is obvious that Ni, Co, and Al are all distributed uniformly on both the pristine NCA precursor and the SDCNCA2 precursor. However, after coating, the content of Al on the precursor surface becomes larger, as shown by the color variation of the Al on the surface displayed in Figure S4. This proves that Al2O3 was successfully coated on the precursor surface. The morphology variation of NCA and SDCNCA cathode materials was also characterized by SEM measurements. As shown in Figure 2, no obvious change in the overall morphology was observed for all of the cathode particles, which means that the nano-Al2O3 spray coating did not damage the general morphology of the NCA particles. As can be seen in Figure 2a, the primary particles of the pristine NCA samples are
extremely obvious with a flakelike shape. Specifically, it can even be seen that there are edges between the primary particles that have different crystallographic orientation, slip planes, and anisotropic lattice. Nevertheless, the SDCNCA particles deliver a slight difference on the surface, as can be seen from Figure 2b−d. Specifically, the edges between the grains blur as if the particles are covered with a layer of gel. The phenomenon is more apparent with higher Al2O3 content. Meanwhile, SEM images as well as the linear-sweep signals of the energydispersive spectrometer images on the cross-section of a single particle were obtained to examine the composition change in the SDCNCA2 sample. The atomic ratio of the three elements Ni, Co, and Al was obtained along the diameter of around 9 μm, as shown in Figure 3. As can be seen, in the SDCNCA2 sample the concentration of Al at the surface becomes a slightly higher than that in the core, with a corresponding decrease of Ni and Co. This confirms that the SDCNCA2 sample is a material with an aluminum-rich surface. TEM observations were further carried out to investigate the microstructure, and the TEM images of the bare and SDCNCA2 samples are displayed in Figure 4. Figure 4a,b reveals that the NCA material is relatively well covered with a coating layer whose thickness is about 10−40 nm. As shown in the HRTEM image of SDCNCA2 (Figure 4d), it is obvious that the planar distance of the outer space is different from that of the inner part (0.2401 and 0.2449 nm, respectively). They display very well developed crystal lattice fringes that are arranged well along the (101) axes of NCA and LiAlO2, respectively, as shown in Table S1. It is completely different from the pristine sample (Figure 4c). Therefore, all of these material characterizations reveal that the NCA precursor coated with Al2O3 by the homogeneous and facile coating method has been successfully synthesized. Meanwhile, this spray-drying coating method confirms a LiAlO2 layer distributed uniformly on the as-prepared cathode material.
3.2. Electrochemical Characterizations. The electrochemical performance was initially subjected to preconditioning cycles at a rate of 0.1C from 2.8 to 4.3 V, as shown in Figure 5a. All of the SDCNCA samples and the pristine one exhibit similar smooth and monotonous charge/discharge profiles. However, the initial discharge capacity is slightly different for these cathode materials. Specifically, the cell based on the
DOI: 10.1021/acsami.6b05629 ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2016, 8, 17713−17720
17715
pristine active material initially delivered a discharge capacity of 188.4 mA h g−1. This is a little higher than those of the SDCNCA samples, which were 186.6, 184.1, and 174.3 mA h g−1 for SDCNCA1, SDCNCA2, and SDCNCA5 respectively. This can mainly be ascribed to the decreased amount of electrochemical active material that is replaced by an insulating alumina coating layer. After activation by two preconditioning cycles at a rate of 0.1C, the cycle performance of all of the samples was tested at a rate of 1C at room temperature, as shown in Figure 5b. The initial discharge capacity at 1C delivered by the pristine sample was 171.1 mA h g−1, compared with 167.2, 165.7, and 154.2 mA h g−1 for SDCNCA1, SDCNCA2, and SDCNCA5, respectively. On the other hand, the capacity retention of the SDCNCA samples was remarkably enhanced, as SDCNCA1, SDCNCA2, and SDCNCA5 delivered retentions of 87.56%, 90.40%, and 93.58% after 150 cycles, respectively, while the pristine electrode suffered a 30.9 mA h g−1 capacity loss and showed only 81.98% retention after 150 cycles. The improvement of the capacity retention shows a superiority to those reported for other coating methods, which mostly displayed retention of <90% under the same testing conditions.35,42−44
Figure 5c shows the rate capacities for all of the samples. As the rate increases, the capacities of the samples decrease. At low
rates (<1C), the SDCNCA samples showed similar discharge capacities as the bare one. However, as shown in the figure, at 2C and 5C those SDCNCA samples exhibited improved capacity retention, with the SNCNCA2 electrode delivering the highest discharge capacity of 162.0 mA h g−1 at 5C, which is 14 mA h g−1 than that of the pristine one. This is mainly due to the more stable structure during cycling, which is ascribed to the coating layer. It is known that the layered Ni-rich cathode materials exhibit a large capacity fade at high temperatures as a result of dissolution of the transition metals due to attack by HF, which is produced by thermal decomposition and hydrolysis of LiPF6 at high temperature.45−47 Thus, Figure 5d shows the cycle performance for all of the samples at 55 °C and a rate of 1C. It is clear that the overall initial discharge capacity at 55 °C was higher than that at 25 °C. This is mainly because of the elevated temperature, which promotes the charge transfer kinetics.47 Obviously, the thermal stability of the LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 cathode material is significantly enhanced by the spray-drying coating method. The initial discharge capacity of the bare electrode was higher than those of the SDCNCA ones, as it was at room temperature, while in the subsequent process, it showed an inferior cycling stability. In particular, the SDCNCA2 sample still retained 85.14% of the initial discharge capacity (181.7 mA h g−1) after 150 cycles under the harsh test conditions, whereas the pristine counterpart exhibited rapid capacity loss and delivered only 133 mA h g−1 (69.78%) after 150 cycles. The thermal stability of Ni-rich cathode materials is an important factor for their applications in EVs and hybrid EVs (HEVs). Therefore, a comparison of DSC traces of the electrochemically delithiated uncoated NCA particles and the SDCNCA2 sample charged to 4.3 V in the electrolyte is shown in Figure 6a. As can be seen, the pristine sample showed a large exothermic peak at 236.5 °C, while the SDCNCA2 one displayed a reaction at a higher temperature of 267.8 °C with a much lower heat flow. This deeply confirms that the spraydrying coating method contributes to a significant improvement in the thermal stability. Figure 6b,c displays another performance in the cycling-test environment with upper voltages of 4.4 and 4.5 V at a rate of 1C at room temperature. It is obvious that the electrochemical properties are significantly influenced by the cutoff voltage and that all of the discharge capacities decreased rapidly as the cycling proceeded. As shown in Figure 6b, after 150 cycles from 2.8 to 4.4 V, the SDCNCA samples delivered capacity
DOI: 10.1021/acsami.6b05629 ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2016, 8, 17713−17720
17716
DOI: 10.1021/acsami.6b05629 ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2016, 8, 17713−17720
17717
retentions of 85.11%, 87.85%, and 90.0% respectively, which are much higher than that of the pristine one (only 66.78% retention of the initial discharge capacity of 180 mA h g−1). Especially, the SDCNCA particles showed stable capacity retention curves even up to 4.5 V, as displayed in Figure 6c. After 150 cycles, the capacity retention of the SDCNCA2 electrode was about 81.1% of the initial capacity (177.6 mA h g−1), compared with only 59.47% for the pristine electrode (initial capacity 189.9 mA h g−1). This indicates that the working voltage of the SDCNCA samples becomes higher than that of the pristine one with this spray-drying coating method. Compared with the bare sample, the electrochemical performance of SDCNCA2 at the high temperature and upper cutoff voltage displays an attractive improvement.48−51
To further understand the origin of the improved cycling performance of the SDCNCA samples, EIS measurements were conducted for the pristine and SDCNCA electrodes after 100 cycles at room temperature, as displayed in Figure 6d. Specifically, the impedance curves can be divided into two parts: a semicircle in the high-frequency region, which stands for the combined surface film and charge transfer resistance (Rsf+ct) at the electrolyte−electrode interface; the sloping line in the low-frequency region represents Li+ diffusion in the solid electrode (Zw).
52,53 It is obvious that the SDCNCA2 sample shows the minimum semicircle, meaning that the surface film and charge transfer resistance is the lowest, which results from the coating layer protecting the particle from the side reactions on the surface. To explore the electrochemical improvement made by the
SDC method, XRD patterns of the pristine and SDCNCA2 electrodes after 100 cycles at a current of 1.0C at room temperature were measured, as shown in Figure 7. As can be seen from Figure 7a, the intensities of the two samples declined after 100 cycles, meaning that the crystal structures of the electrodes suffered from destruction. The magnified regions of the (003) peak, which reflects the change in the c axis,54 are
shown in Figure 7b. It is obvious that both of the (003) reflection peaks are shifted slightly toward the lower-angle region after cycling, indicating that the c axis increases. Although the coating of SDCNCA2 cannot completely prevent the host structure from collapse, it almost restrained the shift of the (003) peak to a lower angle. Therefore, the coating layer is beneficial to stabilize the structure of the LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 cathode material during cycling. Meanwhile, SEM images of the bare NCA electrode and the SDCNCA2 electrode after 100 cycles at 1.0C at room temperature were also obtained to further prove the robust stability of the SDCNCA sample (Figure 7c,d). For the pristine sample (Figure 7d), the particle suffers from severe breaks after the long cycling, mainly because of the continuous HF erosion when the whole surface of NCA particles is entirely exposed to electrolyte together with the side reactions on the surface. In contrast, the SDCNCA2 sample (Figure 7c) still holds the original spherical morphology even after long-term cycling. This is probably because the coating layer on the surface protects the particles from direct contact with the electrolyte, which contributes to improving the structural stability. Therefore, the SDCNCA particles show robust stability both in the cycle tests and in the higher temperature and upper cutoff voltage cycling-test environment. Such an impressive improvement of the electrochemical performance can be ascribed to the LiAlO2 layer on the NCA surface, which acts as a scavenger of HF to maintain the structural stability of the NCA material. The layer not only suppresses the electrode degradation in the aging procedure but also protects the positive material from unwanted interfacial side reactions, as illustrated in Figure 8. This valued feature provides the spray-
drying-coated LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 material with wider operating temperature and voltage ranges with more stable cycle performance when it is used as a cathode material in highperformance applications in EVs and HEVs.

sections.heading: 4. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
With LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 as an example, a layered Ni-rich cathode material coated with a nanoscale LiAlO2 shell on the surface has been synthesized successfully by an advanced facile strategy based on spray-drying coating. SEM and TEM images of the precursor and the cathode materials showed that an Al2O3 layer is distributed uniformly on the precursor surface and a LiAlO2 layer on the host material surface after coating. Such a uniform layer acts as a scavenger to protect the material from attack by HF and serious side reactions. The surface of
DOI: 10.1021/acsami.6b05629 ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2016, 8, 17713−17720
17718
these SDCNCA particles, which consists of a LiAlO2 layer as an insulating layer, effectively improves the structural stability and electrochemical performance, especially in the higher temperature and upper cutoff voltage cycling-test environment. SDCNCA2 delivers a retention of 90.40% after 150 cycles at a rate of 1.0C at room temperature, which is really much higher than that of 81.98% for the bare one. Specifically, it also displays a robust level of reversibility both at higher temperature and upper cutoff voltage. This is mainly due to the significant improvement of the structural stability led by the effective coating strategy, which could be extended to other cathode materials to obtain lithium-ion batteries with enhanced safety and cycling stability.

metadata.abstractText: The electrochemical performance of Ni-rich cathode material at high temperature (>50 °C) and upper voltage operation (>4.3 V) is a challenge for next-generation lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) because of the rapid capacity degradation over cycling. Here we report improved performance of LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 materials via a LiAlO2 coating, which was prepared from a Ni0.80Co0.15Al0.05(OH)2 precursor by spray-drying coating with nano-Al2O3. Investigations by X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, energy-dispersive Xray spectroscopy, and transmission electron microscopy revealed that an Al2O3 layer is uniformly distributed on the precursor and a LiAlO2 layer on the as-prepared cathode material. Such a coating shell acts as a scavenger to protect the cathode material from attack by HF and serious side reactions, which remarkably enhances the cycle performance at 55 °C and upper operating voltage (4.4 and 4.5 V). In particular, the sample with a 2% Al2O3 coating shows capacity retentions of 90.40%, 85.14%, 87.85%, and 81.1% after 150 cycles at a rate of 1.0C at room temperature, 55 °C, 4.4 V, and 4.5 V, respectively, which are significantly higher than those of the pristine one. This is mainly due to the significant improvement of the structural stability led by the effective coating technique, which could be extended to other cathode materials to obtain LIBs with enhanced safety and excellent cycling stability.
